  Tech Bytes: Antimony — the obscure metal that could choke tech supply chains

 
  
 

   
   Published: 07:25 02 Oct 2025 BST
  
 
 
 
 

 
 




 Shares in Nova Minerals Ltd (ASX:NVA, NASDAQ:NVA, OTC:NVAAF) jumped more than 20% on Wednesday, and are up more than 30% this week, after its US subsidiary Alaska Range Resources LLC secured US$43.4 million in Defense Production Act funding to produce antimony trisulfide. The grant, from the US Department of War, is aimed at building a domestic supply of a mineral long critical for military applications — but its relevance goes far beyond the battlefield.

Read more: Nova Minerals unit secures US$43.4 million US DoW award to advance antimony production in Alaska

This little-known element could emerge as one of the most consequential bottlenecks for the global tech economy, sitting at the intersection of defence procurement, electronics manufacturing and the clean energy transition.

Why antimony matters for tech

Antimony is a metalloid with versatile properties. In its oxide form, it is a staple in semiconductors, solar panels and flame-retardant plastics. It also helps stabilise lithium-ion batteries and features in experimental liquid metal batteries designed for long-duration grid storage.

These applications are not optional extras: they sit at the heart of consumer technology and industrial strategy. Without antimony, the production of smartphones, EVs and renewable energy systems becomes harder — and more expensive.

A fragile supply chain

Global supply is precariously concentrated. China mines around half of the world’s antimony and processes closer to 80%, while Russia and Tajikistan provide much of the rest. The US, by contrast, has virtually no domestic production and is highly dependent on imports from strategic competitors.

That makes antimony one of those obscure but strategically sensitive resources. If supply were disrupted, the consequences would cascade across defence supply chains, consumer electronics and the energy transition alike.

The defence driver

Nova’s Alaska Range unit plans to advance its Estelle Gold and Critical Minerals Project in Alaska to refine ore into military-grade antimony trisulfide. The Pentagon’s US$43.4 million award is designed to accelerate that process and seed a fully integrated US antimony supply chain.

For Washington, the imperative is clear: reliable access to a critical input for munitions and defence systems. But the investment in processing and refining could also lay the foundation for commercial supply into civilian markets.

From munitions to microchips

That crossover is what makes antimony so intriguing. A supply chain built to meet military demand could quickly become essential to the wider tech sector. Antimony is used in semiconductor doping, solar cell glass, flame-retardant circuit boards and advanced battery chemistries.

As the US and its allies build capacity to insulate defence industries from supply risk, they may incidentally create a broader platform for supplying the very metals that Silicon Valley, EV makers, and renewable energy developers will increasingly need.

What investors should watch


	Deployment of US funding: The Pentagon’s backing provides a clear runway for Nova to progress its plans and demonstrates strong government commitment to building capacity.
	Scaling production: Advancing from exploration to refining will be the next key step, with opportunities to establish a fully integrated US antimony supply chain.
	Broader market opportunities: While the immediate driver is defence, the same infrastructure could open up supply to semiconductors, solar panels and batteries, expanding addressable markets.
	Growing global interest: With antimony now firmly on the strategic minerals radar, further industry partnerships and government initiatives may accelerate development.


The bigger picture

Antimony may not carry the buzz of lithium or rare earths, yet its strategic value is rising quickly. Yesterday’s funding deal highlights how even relatively obscure minerals can move markets and redraw supply chains. Nova’s breakthrough shows the Pentagon is serious about securing antimony — and if it succeeds, the tech industry could be a major beneficiary.

For now, antimony remains an underappreciated piece of the critical minerals puzzle. But as the scramble to secure supply intensifies, investors, governments, and tech manufacturers alike may discover that the fate of their chips, batteries, and solar panels rests on this lesser-known metalloid.
